Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Large: Collaborative Research: Design Principles for Information Networks Supporting the Social Production of Knowledge

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project seeks to develop design principles for social computing applications in which knowledge is produced by large, loosely coordinated groups of people. The research will be carried out by an inter-disciplinary team that brings together expertise from computing and information science with the social sciences; perspectives from all of these areas will be crucial to developing the next generation of large-scale collaborative information systems on the Internet. A particular focus of the research will be on phenomena that affect the quality of information and discussion in these settings, including deception and the kinds of opinion dynamics that lead to polarization. The research will offer new analysis techniques and computational models for understanding such phenomena, drawing on novel styles of investigation involving large-scale datasets of social interaction and social network activity. Building on this, the research will also formulate design principles (based on ideas from intelligent task routing and games with a purpose) to enable creators of social computing applications to design for particular outcomes in the presence of complex underlying social phenomena.

The project is motivated by a profound transformation taking place in the way knowledge is produced and shared; in particular, the way it emerges in a "bottom-up" manner from global social networks that largely self-organize online. This raises profound challenges: at a time when a large proportion of Americans turn first to Internet sources for information about politics, health, commerce, and education, there is still very little understanding among the public as well as within the research community of how to deal with deception and misinformation online, or how to prevent online communities from falling into conflict and polarization. Through its focus on design principles and on these challenges, the project will attempt to create more effective means of online discourse and knowledge production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project developed design principles for on-line social systems, including social networks, social media, and digital forums and discussion environments. Over the past decade, these systems have come to play an increasingly central role both in technological settings and in society generally, and it has become correspondingly important to have principled methods for designing new systems and for understanding and predicting their behavior. 

The intellectual merit of the project has been based on research results that explored design principles in three distinct dimensions: the quality of on-line information, the polarity of on-line information, and the development of mechanisms to help people accomplish on-line tasks. 

In the area of information quality, the project defined several new metrics for on-line information, and provided the first algorithms to compute them. A key metric in the project was notion of memorability -- the extent to which a piece of text is picked up and spread by participants in the system. The concept of memorability led to a number of pieces of follow-up work, including new methods for assessing the "virality" of text, and the application of these methods to analyze information-sharing behavior on Twitter and other social-media sites. The project also analyzed the interplay between social and informational cues in information-sharing, applying this approach to the design of new socially-based content recommendation systems. 

The project also focused on the polarity of information -- the extent to which it expresses positive or negative sentiment. Project participants developed text analysis methods to infer the positive or negative polarity of relationships from the text of communications between people; they also used text analysis to analyze levels of positive and negative emotion in social media posts over human diurnal cycles, finding strong recurring patterns in the daily flow of information. The project applied such notions of positive and negative information to the prediction of ratings and evaluations in on-line social networks, and to the design of more effective mobile health applications that enabled users to express both positive and negative emotional responses. 

Finally, the project studied mechanisms for managing on-line tasks, and motivating individuals to complete tasks. Project participants developed new algorithms for constructing systems of badges that create incentives to reach designated milestones. They applied these badge systems in several settings, including forums for on-line courses. The project extended this line of work by incorporating principles from behavioral economics, providing a new integration of computational and behavioral principles in designing task structures that could be efficiently performed even in the presence of behavioral biases such as procrastination. 

The project has had several broader impacts. Graduate students supported by the project have gone on to positions in the faculties of leading universities and in the engineering and data-science groups of some of the main companies in the social media space. The methods developed by the project have helped inform developments in on-line social networking, recommendation systems, product-review sites, mobile health platforms, and a number of other widespread applications. Finally, ideas originating in the project have helped influence the curricula of a number of large courses that introduce the principles underlying on-line information to student audiences both on-campus and through on-line courses.
